Situation1: They are asked to take part in an important family event like a holiday celebration or trip.
Expectation2: Communicate with clients and vendors regarding financial matters.
Situation2: A vendor sent a standard automated confirmation of a recent payment, to which a formal reply should be sent.
Story:
I stared at my phone, the group chat with my family lighting up with messages about the holiday dinner tonight. My sister sent a reminder: “Don’t forget, you promised to help set up and be there early!” I could almost hear my mom’s voice, hoping I’d finally make it on time and not be glued to my laptop. 

But just as I was about to leave, an email notification popped up from one of our vendors. It was a standard payment confirmation, but protocol required a formal reply—something my boss always emphasized. “Timely communication is key,” he’d said in my last review. I knew if I didn’t respond before the end of the business day, it would reflect poorly on my professionalism.

I felt the pressure mounting. My family expected me to be present, to laugh and share stories, to be the brother they missed. My job demanded prompt, precise replies, even for routine matters. I stood in the hallway, keys in one hand, phone in the other, torn between the warmth of home and the cold necessity of work, my heart pounding as I weighed which role to disappoint.
